poem:
**Carmen in Covent Garden**  

A flurry of notes beneath velvet skies,  
Aigul dances in embers of Gypsy fire,  
while Elder conducts the night like a new constellation.  
The youth hums along,  
a troupe in syncopated breath,  
and the opera house feels small,  
a captivated box, as the world spins outside,  
unaware of the enchantment within.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Carmen review – Akhmetshina and Elder make this an outstanding evening The latest of several strong Covent Garden revivals of core repertoire this season, this Carmen may be the best of the lot. The new run has two outstanding things going for it, in the shape of Mark Elder’s conducting and Aigul Akhmetshina’s return to the title role. But there is plenty of vigorous underpinning elsewhere, particularly in the energy of its largely youthful cast.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
